history.text: This sounds like an interesting movie.  Christopher Nolan does a good job directing it sounds like.

As a fan of sci-fi, this movie definitely piqued my curiosity. Delving into other people's dreams using secret military tech and changing their minds from the inside? Awesome. Nolan usually knows how to weave a story.
I'm familiar with all the actors, except Ellen Page, but it sounds like they all do a good job from the 8.1 rating it got.
Ellen Page is a young up and comer. I know her from some work she's done in video games. Solid actress, and the cast worked well together.
It said DiCaprio played the tortured hero.  That would be an interesting role for him.
That last review made me laugh, even though it sounds a bit try-hard in its sarcasm.
Yeah, I couldn't tell if it was serious or not, but you're right that it sounds like sarcasm.
Labeling the genre as "scientific" seems odd to me as well. What the heck kind of genre for a movie is that?
Haha, I didn't even notice that until now.  You would think it would say "science fiction" instead.
What a great cast overall though. Hardy, DiCaprio, and Gordon-Levitt is definitely a pretty elite group of relevant actors.
I love that the world is so fleshed out. It's great to see such thought put into something new like this, rather than just building on what's already out there.
Yeah, I'm trying to figure out if there are any true villains in this movie.
That's a good point. I guess the villain's are challenge based instead of actually people. Nifty.
Saito apparently set the whole thing up himself.
I think it's interesting that Fischer not only knew about this tech but apparently underwent some training to work against it, as well.
Dying in a dream and not waking up would be freaky.  I've never died in a dream.  I heard it was impossible, but it says that Cobb died in his dream.

Thankfully, I've always been a bit of a lucid dreamer. Even as a kid I could change nightmares into harmless dreams. But this limbo thing sounds freaky. It would be nuts not being to tell the difference between dreams and reality.
Yeah, it says Mal committed suicide because she thought she was dreaming and wanted to get out of the dream.
Poor Cob. You obviously wouldn't be able to use the limbo/dream state as an excuse in a court.
They were only sedated for a few hours but I guess it seemed like 50 years in dream world.
I don't think Cobb could be blamed or the suicide though
That's one way to extend your life, I suppose. If didn't... you know... drive you to suicide and all that.
Knowing how Nolan tells stories, I love how it ends without you knowing if Cobb is still in a dream or not. Classic.
I didn't even understand that part yet, haha.
I could see that pissing off a lot of people though.
It sounds like Fischer is told that his father wants him to be his own man
Yeah, movies with questions at the end of them does anger people sometimes.
So mission successful. Interesting that it uses some pretty shady tech to come to a good outcome.
Yeah, it sounds like it could never happen in real life even with all the new technology.
It would definitely give someone power though if they could control your subconscience.

I don't know... there's some pretty crazy mind reading tech out there right now. There is literally stuff that can read brainwaves and reproduce the image on a screen. Doesn't seem all that much of a leap to "convince" someone of what they are thinking.
Hmm, that's dangerous.
So at the end Cobb ignores the result and then it never tells the audience whether he is in a dream or not?
That's what it looks like, yeah.
Huh, yeah I would wish for a more definite ending.
Yeah, I don't mind endings up for interpretation, but in this case it would be nice to at least give an indication one way or the other.
I still don't know how Cobb is faced with a murder charge if it was suicide.
I think they set it up so that you couldn't really tell.
So basically he's being framed for the murder, but he can't prove it.
That seems like a pretty crappy card to be dealt, for sure.
Yeah, well I don't know what else to say about it.  Should we end the conversation?
Sounds good. I think I've said everything as well. Good conversation!
